Oliver Hardy.Action: Worried expression talking about a past relationship's unexpected demand for money.
Admits he lost money in a bet with Mysterious Montague but asks Laurel not to discuss money with Hal today.
Gives extra money as a tip to the studio runner Burgess.
Flirts briefly with a passing chorus girl but quickly refocuses on business.
Expresses doubts about business plans due to practical concerns but remains engaged in discussion with Laurel.
Invites Stan to join him on a sail boat trip, mentioning presence of ladies and a friend.
Expresses dislike to talk business while working, showing consideration for group harmony.
Catches Lucille's eye and gives her a secret smile, then kisses the tips of his fingers and blows them to her.
Greets James Finlayson warmly with 'Hey Jimmie.'
Suggests to Stan to hold off leaving and push the director for a raise.
Thinks about protesting but accepts the truth silently, showing some self-awareness but also passivity.
Appears surprised when Laurel reveals plan to set up on their own, indicating he may not be fully aware or involved in plans.
Gives Lucille a small, helpless shrug during Roach's outburst.
Calmly comments 'Well that went well...' after Roach storms out.
Shares concerns about his physical condition openly with Laurel.
Considers keeping up with physical challenges despite discomfort.
Maybe I’ll punch you in the throat.
Hardy looks thoughtfully out the window, reflecting quietly before acting.
Hardy expresses frustration with a half-joking threat to Laurel.
Raises concerns about scheduling conflicts in a professional manner during discussion with Delfont.
Questions Stan's actions with puzzlement and irritation, emphasizing the priority of their work over distractions.
Reflects thoughtfully on the lawyer's arrangement being 'comforting', indicating some awareness and confidence in the business side.
Pompously places valise on desk, tries to stop Laurel from ringing bell, explains the situation clearly to receptionist, signs in register with flourish, handles interaction confidently.
Gets irritated with Laurel's repeated bell ringing and squabble, pushes Laurel in frustration.
Forgets the name of the theatre they are appearing at.
Accepts Stan’s correction about the venue without assertiveness, leading to awkward silence.
Looks around expectantly for a Bell Boy to assist, showing reliance on others in a situation where none are available.
Responds with sarcasm to Stan’s suggestion to work late, revealing some reluctance but agreeing nonetheless.
Voices a wish to be with Laurel during the signing, showing affection and emotional connection.
Speaks warmly on the phone to his wife, describing environment positively and with enthusiasm; polite and friendly to receptionist.
Makes a transatlantic call to his wife while being polite and warm, describing their surroundings confidently and with ease.
Turns away discreetly when the night porter is watching him, then blows a kiss down the phone with affection.
Appears thoughtful and serious when reflecting on his relationship with Stan, showing emotional intelligence.
Wears unfamiliar attire and appears plainly uncomfortable on set, indicating possible insecurity or unease in a professional environment.
Sits on a stool next to an elephant with a hot water bottle on its head, playing a vet in a comical or awkward role, showing acceptance of an unusual situation.
Nervously asks his wife if the first day on set will be okay, showing some doubt and lack of confidence in the immediate situation.
Looks over to the Laurel look-alike and involuntarily stiffens at the touch, showing discomfort and a sense of loyalty to Stan Laurel.
Notices crew members avoiding eye contact with him, reflecting his own feelings of guilt or betrayal regarding Stan Laurel.
Returns a polite smile to Harry Langdon despite feeling uncomfortable, maintaining civility and professionalism.
Receives last minute instructions while looking totally preoccupied and visibly uncomfortable about working with a Laurel look-alike, showing emotional unease but continues to engage politely.
Responds with a polite smile to Harry Langdon's mimicry of Laurel, indicating social grace despite internal discomfort.
Struggles emotionally with the idea of replacing Stan Laurel, showing hesitation and lack of confidence in the new partnership.
Approaches Laurel suspiciously but then offers cigarette and Scotch, sharing in a friendly and convivial manner.
Makes light banter and expresses concern about their accommodations and the girls, showing a caring attitude.
Snatches cigarettes and lights up confidently, sharing with Laurel.
Produces a hidden bottle of Scotch and pours drinks for both, displaying resourcefulness.
Expresses concern about their accommodations and plans to improve situation for upcoming guests.
Looks suspiciously at the sandwich filling but tries it anyway after adding salt, responding positively to Stan's idea and laughter.
Joins in the playful act, uses the shoe horn effectively as a pretend sword, and mirrors Laurel’s kneeling pose despite physical discomfort, showing adaptability and commitment to the bit.
Physically strains to kneel on his shoes and continue the joke, showing dedication but some physical awkwardness and vulnerability.
Sits quietly with a leg in a plaster cast, showing no complaint or fuss despite being injured.
Laughs along warmly with Stan and Billy Brady, acknowledges Billy's grandfather with friendly familiarity.
Responds wittily to Billy Brady's comment, showing confidence and ease.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Stan, making jokes about their relationship to amuse the audience.
Thanks Stan sincerely after receiving the Scotch.
Instinctively looks at his watch while struggling up the stairs, inadvertently causing the trunk to fall.
Makes a self-deprecating comment 'I know my place' but doesn’t lash out or hurt Stan’s feelings.
Responds with mild frustration when Stan doesn’t warn tea was cold, but does not escalate the situation.
Interrupts discussion to perform a complex tea ritual carefully, showing habitual precision.
Admits confusion about medication (red vs. blue tablets) and takes both simultaneously without understanding potential consequences.
Takes medication without checking temperature of tea, resulting in swallowing cold medication with displeasure.
Discloses 'I know my place' in a self-deprecating manner with some irony yet does not assert himself.
Expresses sadness about Billy Brady working while dying, showing empathy
Takes a sip from Laurel's flask while discussing sombre topics, showing informal trust and comfort
Is distracted and can't concentrate while reading the script; shows frustration and drinks from a flask repeatedly.
Engages in a quiet, reflective conversation acknowledging deep emotional concerns.
Politely greets elderly couple with a smile and a doff of the beret.
Agrees to Laurel's suggestion graciously, showing cooperative and considerate nature.
Acknowledges he's not well enough to do the dance and agrees to Laurel’s suggestion.
Does not directly answer Laurel’s repeated question about trousers, responds dismissively with 'Never mind.'
Confidently plays ukulele and sings beautifully despite health issues.
Sweats heavily and shows physical toll but still maintains polite and hopeful conversation about improving their act.
Responds politely and gratefully to Delfont's critiques.
Expresses concern about the small theatres and defends the tour continuation despite poor reception.
Explains clearly and sincerely the reason for touring (availability for movie), showing openness and commitment.
Firmly insists on the necessity of continuing the tour to Delfont, showing earnestness and trustworthiness.
Questions the decision to book small theatres and expresses frustration clearly and logically.
Firmly reminds that the tour was intended to support the movie production, emphasizing priorities and commitment.
Appears somewhat defensive when health is questioned but maintains focus on the need to continue the tour.
Expresses frustration about having to work hard for no extra money ('That we would have to flog ourselves half to death for nothing?') but ultimately agrees.
Smiles to fans and eats chips happily despite Hardy looking pale and exhausted later.
Waits for his cue patiently, then joins Laurel on stage with impeccable timing and expressions, contributing to mutual laughter and audience enjoyment.
Joins Stan in offering to celebrate and shares food preferences in friendly manner

Expresses confidence in the positive turn of their career and accepts congratulations, showing steady optimism and professionalism.
Responds with enthusiasm and decisiveness about dinner choice, indicating clear preference and decisiveness.
Smiles at a joke, shows camaraderie with Laurel.
Expresses concern about the future of their work and the movie project to Laurel.
Expresses concern about the future of their touring and the importance of the movie, showing awareness and planning.
Smiles broadly and hums a cheerful tune while strolling down the street.
Walks happily, humming and singing softly despite forgetting some lyrics, exhibiting relaxed confidence and joie de vivre.
Selects a red carnation with great delicacy, pays kindly, hums cheerfully while carrying on jauntily into the tube station.
Selects a red carnation with great delicacy, pays for it carefully, and pins it to his lapel while humming and whistling jauntily.
Makes a humorous comment about Stan getting a new job, creating a lighthearted atmosphere.
Smiles politely at the assistant and explains the bracelet is a gift for his wife arriving from overseas.
Reveals he does not have enough money to pay now but asks the assistant to hold the bracelet, promising to return shortly.

Considers purchasing an expensive diamond and ruby bracelet as a gift, interacts politely and thoughtfully with the shop assistant, and manages his lack of funds by asking the assistant to hold the item while he fetches the money.
Does not immediately realize he lacks sufficient money before expressing interest in the purchase, potentially leading to an awkward situation.
Makes a phone call placing a bet, politely thanking the concierge and maintaining friendly conduct.
Uses a public phone to place a precise bet, clearly counts money accurately and confirms the amount before instructing the bet to be placed.
Pays attention to racing news and faces disappointment calmly, forces a smile when noticed by children.
Is puzzled by Laurel’s counting logic but tries to engage in conversation thoughtfully.
Reluctantly nods to cooperate with Stan's idea, showing tolerance and teamwork.
Waits by the door with back turned, seemingly unaware of Laurel and the girls’ position.
Greets the wives politely and is affectionate, showing social grace and control in a public setting.
Reassures LUCILLE she can visit wherever she likes, calls her 'my angel'
Mentions they have been counting the days until LUCILLE arrived, shows obvious affection
Responds immediately to LUCILLE’s admonition about salt, apologizes sincerely
Purposefully avoids eye contact and nervously adds salt to his food, showing discomfort and poor self-management.
Stops adding salt immediately when reminded by Lucille, showing ability to respond to feedback.
Reveals reliable knowledge regarding the movie production and Stan's script rewrite, demonstrating awareness and involvement.
Takes care of his health by ensuring he takes tablets, though somewhat passively relying on Stan.
Deflects concerns nervously and glares at Stan to stop joking at inappropriate moments.
Buys Lucille a huge bunch of flowers and tries to spoil her.
Jokes about financial worries but is comforted by Lucille's reassurance, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Cuddles with Lucille and expresses affection openly.
Says 'Easy as pie' agreeing with Stan about the river jump, showing confidence and reassurance.
Jokes about only buying things he can’t afford, revealing low mood despite humor.
Lies on bed watching Lucille arranging flowers, appearing passive and possibly disengaged.
Laughs warmly at Lucille's protective comment about Stanley.
Allows Lucille to stroke his forehead gently when he is tired and struggling.
Paces nervously backstage, showing vulnerability before the show.
Looks to the applauding audience and gestures for Laurel to come back on stage.
Paces nervously backstage before the show.
Energetically engages with Stan, encourages playful creativity despite Stan's distress.
Insensitive to Stan's mood, continues playfully joking without addressing Stan's visible distress.
Energetically runs lines from the script, looks for ways to improve the performance, and encourages creative thinking.
Asks Stan for help (out of character), indicating trust and reliance.
Tries to calm Lucille down with gentle words: 'Come on honey, if the script says I fall in the river, that’s what I have to do.'
Formal polite address to guests expressing pleasure and humility.
Tries to calm Lucille down and insists on following the script despite objections, showing professionalism and calmness.
Steps forward to address guests formally and with humility, showing confidence and social competence.
Attempts to formally address guests and express gratitude.
Embarrassed by Lucille’s loud criticism and tries unsuccessfully to calm her down.
Trying to calm things down during a tense confrontation
Steers Stan Laurel away from a potentially difficult social situation
Tries to calm the escalating confrontation between Lucille and Ida.
Abruptly excuses himself and Stan Laurel to remove them from an awkward social situation.
Attempts to explain his past actions and circumstances, showing some vulnerability about being broke.
Labels Stan as a 'pain in the ass' and attributes blame to him for difficulties, lacks tact.
Admits wanting people to like him and to be hired, showing desire for acceptance.
Rubs painful knee and expresses desire to maintain good relations for work, showing self-awareness and pragmatism.
Accuses Stan of being overly focused on 'stuff' but admits wanting to be liked and hired.
Dismisses friendship, belittles Laurel by calling him hollow and empty.
Keeps his dignity and chooses not to retaliate when hit by a bread roll.
Keeps his dignity after being hit by the bread roll and decides not to retaliate, showing emotional control and restraint.
Throws the beret given by Laurel back at him, signaling anger but also taking clear action.
Openly acknowledges motivations for their partnership and friendship being practical rather than emotional, showing pragmatic thinking.
Leaves without informing Laurel, avoids his gaze, and refuses Stan's offer to pour tea, asking organizer instead.
Avoids eye contact with Laurel, leaves without him, asks the organizer to pour tea instead of doing it himself.
Remains silent and does not join Laurel onstage despite encouragement, appears withdrawn and unresponsive before fainting.
Refuses to join Laurel on stage despite cues, remains still and unengaged, ultimately faints mid-act.
Refuses medical help when weakly saying 'No doctor...' despite serious condition.
Refuses a doctor's help even when in poor condition.
Refuses hospital admission despite doctor's advice and clear medical evidence of a heart attack and congestive failure.
Gives a weak but genuine smile to Laurel, shares eggs with him, shows openness about his retirement and health condition, offers reassurance to Laurel with 'Je ne regret rien.'
Expresses understanding and concern about Laurel's feelings despite his own distress.
Challenges Laurel gently about lying and shows disappointment, indicating a desire for honesty and trust.
Presses Laurel to be honest about work progress on his sickbed, showing concern and insight.
Decides to retire due to heart condition, showing realistic assessment of his own limits.
Laughs and appreciates Stan’s idea, also adds suggestion about props, showing practical collaboration and engagement.
Struggles physically with coughing fits and exhaustion, requiring assistance and blankets.
Confidently accepts retirement and encourages Stan to move on with a new partner, showing decisiveness.
Returns to gazing at the ceiling after making a decision, showing some withdrawal or lack of further engagement.
Smiles alone in bed recalling shared humorous moments and camaraderie with Stan
Engages in playful banter and mock confrontation with Robin Hood and Laurel, showing good-natured tolerance and friendly interaction.
Attempts to physically strike Robin Hood despite being warned, leading to his own injury.
Punches Stan Laurel in the throat out of annoyance, escalating conflict physically.
Sits in the river, frustrated but composes himself enough to pull out a salmon and throw it away.
Lies in bed, silently crying, emotionally vulnerable while his partner talks obliviously.
Imitates Hardy-style moustache as lighthearted comedic preparation backstage.
Stares ahead thoughtfully, does not speak to Lucille although she speaks to him cheerfully, appears lost in his thoughts.
Arrives pale and unsteady but determined to see Stan before he leaves, despite ill health.
Stands outside Laurel's door looking pale and unsteady but with clear eyes and a determined expression.
Speaks gently to Stan inviting him to sit with him while telling the women to go ahead, showing care for Stan.
Ignores Lucille's concern about catching pneumonia and insists on staying in the fresh air wrapped in a blanket.
Despite being pale and unsteady, stands with clear eyes and determined expression, showing resolve.
Lies on deck wrapped in a blanket in cold weather, refusing to heed advice to get out of the wind, risking illness.
Smiles when receiving the beret back, watches Laurel with concern, admits he knew about the movie's cancellation but allowed Laurel to continue rehearsing.
Recognizes Stan’s lie and has known the truth for weeks, but keeps it to himself to avoid conflict.
Expresses resignation but supports continued rehearsing despite knowing no movie is coming.
Rejects the food with disgust and makes a sarcastic comment to the audience.
Downplays his exhaustion and insists on continuing, shows determination but not warmth explicitly.
Delivers engaging stage banter and manages audience interaction smoothly.
Corrects Stan's geographic mistake politely (Dublin not in Scotland).
Perseveres through physical illness to perform skillfully on stage.

Stan Laurel.Action: Considers Hardy’s dilemma quietly without judgment or criticism.
Finishes fastening a frayed cuff with a paper clip for a cuff-link.
Suggests sticking together and renegotiating contract terms with Hal rather than giving up.
Offers reassurance to Hardy with humor and a hug after Hardy shares personal news about his engagement.
Promises to be 'nice as pie' to avoid antagonizing Hal.
Declines Hardy’s invitation politely because of work commitments, engaging in friendly banter.
Responds politely and calmly to the angry studio boss Hal Roach with 'Good morning Hal.'
Turns to Hardy embarrassed to reveal a private issue about his wife Ruthie and a fight, showing openness and vulnerability.
Uses the word 'parvenu' confidently to insult Hardy and explains its meaning, showing vocabulary and wit.
Leads conversation about contract and setting up on their own, demonstrating initiative and strategic thinking.
Suggests the wide two-shot he wants to director Horne.
Jokes playfully about punching Hardy, makes him laugh.
Offers to talk to the producer to accommodate Hardy's physical issues.
It’s swell of you to come up here to meet us Mr. Delfont.
Pulls a beret from his pocket and demonstrates folding it neatly, showing a practical and inventive use.
Struggles to carry heavy luggage, repeatedly rings bell despite Hardy's irritation, slaps Hardy's hand back, looks confused and guilty, starts to cry.
Gives a smile to the receptionist and tries to get attention politely at first.
Correctly remembers and states the name of the Queen’s Hall when Hardy forgets.
Proposes running lines despite the late hour, showing initiative and commitment to work.
Tries to smile at Schenck despite tension; showing patience and good-natured effort to ease the situation.
Interacts politely and cooperatively with his lawyer, taking and giving back pen and contract without frustration or rudeness.
Signs contract leaving Hardy's signature blank, possibly showing respect or deference to Hardy.
Hesitates and shows minor confusion handling the contract and pen, needing to take back the pen from the lawyer before signing.
Proceeds to sign the contract himself despite Hardy not being present, indicating initiative and readiness to move forward.
Nods miserably and goes along with Hardy’s playful accusation, then shares cigarette and drink with him, smiling warmly.
Corrects Hardy gently on the name 'Miffin' despite Hardy’s teasing, showing patience and tolerance.
Quickly stubs out cigarette and hides ashtray to avoid detection.
Going along with Hardy's theatrical sniffing 'for fun,' showing a relaxed and cooperative attitude.
Offers reassurance about theatre venue and agrees to act on Hardy's concern regarding hotels.
Corrects Hardy's pronunciation of 'Miffin,' showing attention to detail.
Waiting on an important call regarding shooting dates, indicating some reliance on external information but no active follow-up shown here.
Shares an idea for a movie title and laughs while telling a story, making Hardy laugh too.
Creates a playful scenario using a shoe horn as a sword and hides under the curtain for comedic effect, demonstrating inventive humor and control over the scene.
Laughs at himself and embraces silliness, maintaining the comedic flow rather than becoming frustrated or breaking character.
Makes a transatlantic call to Ida, expressing how much he misses her and concern about the small theatre, showing care and sincerity.
Reassures Ida about Oliver Hardy doing fine, showing trust and support.
Shakes Billy Brady's hand warmly, warmly acknowledges and praises Billy's grandfather, expresses sincere sympathy upon learning he passed away.
Goes through his pre-show ritual meticulously checking cuffs and boots to ensure no heels for comedic effect.
Shows warm recognition and respect when meeting the stage hand, demonstrating social awareness and emotional intelligence.
Shows sincerity and empathy when learning about the death of Billy Brady's grandfather.
Brings flowers and hard boiled eggs to Hardy despite restrictions, ensuring Hardy feels supported.
Silently counts in his head before joining Hardy on stage, appearing emotionally affected but maintaining professionalism.
Lets Oliver Hardy retrieve the heavy trunk that fell down the stairs, accepting a difficult task without complaint.
Brings two Scotches for both himself and Hardy, then gently wakes Hardy and offers him a drink.
Offers to run new scenes but immediately says they don’t have to if Hardy doesn’t want to.
Lightly jokes about the tablets getting jealous and fighting over Hardy, showing gentle humor and care.
Pays attention to Hardy’s health and asks about his knee and medication.
Proposes running new scenes for 'Rob 'Em Good', shows initiative and creative input.
Gently corrects Hardy's medication mix-up, demonstrating awareness and concern.
Does not react negatively to Hardy's barb and manages the conversation delicately.
Reflects with sympathy on Jimmy Finlayson's lonely death and the sadness of old colleagues still working or alone
Makes a polite phone call, responding warmly to Mr. Miffin
Gives a humorous but false reason for Hardy's absence to the caller
Reflects thoughtfully on the lives of others, engaging in a meaningful conversation about aging and work.
Makes a phone call on behalf of Hardy, handling communications proactively while Hardy is unavailable.
Gives Hardy a present (another beret), shows thoughtfulness and delight in Hardy's happiness.
Courteously ends phone call to avoid interrupting, shows consideration and patience.
Politely greets elderly couple with a smile and a doff of the beret.
Shows concern for Hardy's well-being, suggests Hardy sing while he dances instead of Hardy doing the dance himself.
Throws Hardy a knowing look to suggest an adjustment in the performance given Hardy’s health.
Shows some uncertainty about why they are not wearing trousers, asking twice.
Harmonizes gently and performs a coordinated soft shoe shuffle while Hardy sings.
Contributes ideas helpfully and speaks optimistically about their new routines and future performances.
Shows surprise and concern when hearing the tour might be closed prematurely, emphasizes importance of family coming to see them.
Supports Hardy and shows loyalty by backing the importance of finishing the tour and welcoming family.
Suddenly realizes the implications of the situation and voices concern about closing down early, showing awareness and proactiveness.
Reacts emotionally (thunderstruck) to the negative news, showing surprise and confusion, but then articulates the problem clearly.
Responds to unpleasant news with optimism and determination ('We can turn it around.' and 'We'll do it.').
Puts his bag of chips over Hardy’s so Hardy gets all the vinegar, then takes his own bag away before Hardy notices.
Looks around puzzled for Hardy, then checks his watch and goes to find him.
Offers to host dinner to celebrate success and mentions wives arriving soon
Smiles and clinks glass with Hardy in toast to their success
Acknowledges a successful show with delight and participates in a celebratory toast, showing awareness of their achievement and future prospects.

Contradicts Hardy's meal choice but clarifies politely, reflecting attention to personal needs and clear communication.
Smiles and clinks glass in toast with Hardy.
Reassures Hardy that the movie is happening despite struggles.
Is taken off guard by Hardy's question about the movie's status, but reassures him confidently.
Smiles and nods politely to the bell boys at the hotel.
Tries to smile back at the man with boss-eyed eyes despite noticing his unusual appearance.
Dresses smartly in business attire, displays energy and expectation, studies competition (Abbott & Costello) thoughtfully.
Pauses and observes the man with crossed eyes with polite social awareness but no obvious reaction beyond a double take.
Does not correct receptionist's mispronunciation of his name, patiently waits despite being told Mr. Miffin is not present and may be a while.
Checks the address against a slip of paper before entering the building, demonstrating attention to detail.
Does not correct the receptionist's repeated mispronunciation of his name, indicating a lack of assertiveness or attention to detail in communication.
Decides to wait patiently despite being told the person he wants to see is not present, showing persistence and adaptability.
Absent from the scene, referenced only as ‘just got himself a new job, mending broken biscuits’—no direct actions or competence indicators.
Tries to amuse the receptionist with playful antics despite no response, showing patience and good-natured effort to connect.
Gives up on making the receptionist laugh after several attempts, showing tolerance and understanding of her discomfort.
Attempts to entertain the receptionist with whimsical, silly gestures but fails to gain any positive response and ultimately gives up.
Ignores the receptionist’s request to wait and forcibly opens the closed office door, walking in without permission.
Politely greets Cynthia Clarke and listens quietly as she explains the difficult situation regarding the film’s financing.
Remains polite despite being crushed by disappointing news.
Shrugs blankly and appears confused when questioned about counting days.
Greets wife Ida warmly with a kiss and tries to include both wives gracefully despite potential awkwardness.
Leads the wives around the limousine to Hardy’s side despite initial confusion, successfully reuniting with Hardy and entering the hotel together.
Feigns confusion when blocked by Hardy’s open door, showing some hesitation.

Jokes about knocking on Buckingham Palace's door to ask for sugar, lightening the mood.
Tells Lucille the movie is set up and ready after the tour, indicating planning and organization.
Says he has been giving Hardy the green tablets instead of the correct ones, joking inappropriately at a serious moment.

Smiles and acknowledges Ida's comment about Oliver's behavior with a tolerant and understanding tone.
Defends staying committed to past issues as ‘all in the past, where it should stay.’
Refuses the Scotch politely despite social pressure.
Allows himself a smile seeing the packed auditorium, checks details to be ready for the show.
Continues to toy with the Scotch despite Ida’s warning about his diabetes.
Pretends to argue with someone in the wings, slowly walks back on stage.
Holds the tumbler up to his nose and breathes in the aroma of the Scotch, showing a careful and deliberate approach.
Checks the paper clips on his cuffs and confirms no heels on his boots before going onstage, exhibiting attention to detail and preparation.
Walks out on stage but accidentally goes into the wings, requiring Hardy to gesture him back, then pretends to argue to cover the mistake.
Feels guilty and downcast about the canned movie and struggles with telling Hardy the truth.
Decides to delay confession to Hardy in favor of creating something humorous together.
Struggles with guilt about bad news but ultimately diverts from confessing to focus on creativity.
Helps Hardy by holding his arm as Hardy lowers himself to the ground with difficulty.
Spreads hands in a helpless gesture and admits ‘I didn’t put it there’ with reluctance.
Is plunged into guilty secret and remains silent during Babe and Lucille's argument.
Spreads his hands in a helpless gesture and admits 'I didn’t put it there' indicating uncertainty or lack of confidence in the scene.
Is plunged back into a guilty secret when confronted with disagreement about the scene, showing internal conflict and hesitation.
Taps Hardy several times while he is speaking, eventually snapping at him in front of guests.
Grabs a glass of champagne without thinking, then hands it to Ida who drinks it.
Attempts to deescalate situation by suggesting they return to the room after tension rises.
Passively follows Hardy when steered away, not attempting to manage or influence the situation.
Opens up about frustrations and remains honest about his feelings regarding being fired and negotiation issues.
Accuses Hardy of neglect and not supporting him in negotiations, shows resentment.
Encourages Oliver to play a round with Babe while he sleeps on a couch in the editing suite.
Continues working even when Hardy is injured and resting in the editing suite.
Criticizes Hardy for not standing up, but also takes on the workload during Hardy's injury.
Argues passionately but internally feels put upon, showing both commitment and possible friction with Hardy.
Expresses hurt and accuses Hardy of betrayal, admits he loved their partnership.
Throws a bread roll at Hardy in response to being thrown the beret.
Throws a bread roll at Hardy but does so hesitantly, showing limited assertiveness and lacking a more effective confrontation.
Expresses emotional confusion and accuses Hardy, demonstrating emotional openness but not clear problem-solving skill.
Offers to pour tea for Hardy despite his evident coldness and tension.
Offers to pour himself a cup of tea, shows willingness to help the organizer and participate cooperatively.

Expresses gratitude to the audience, attempts to engage Hardy to join him onstage, gently admonishes Hardy to stop sulking, shows immediate concern and helps Hardy after he faints, asks tenderly what is wrong with him.
Manages the stage interaction smoothly despite Hardy's reluctance, keeps the audience engaged, handles the envelope and tiara exchange competently, tries to prompt Hardy to join him.
Shows quick thinking and concern by attending to Hardy promptly when he faints, helps him into recovery position, calms the crowd.
Helps a semi-conscious Hardy alone across the foyer and corridor, struggles painfully but persists, and shows concern by explaining Hardy's condition sincerely to Lucille.
Admits to needing help aloud when Bell Boys are not helping and accepts their laughter without hostility.
Apologizes sincerely to Lucille for the situation and expresses regret.
Struggles to support and carry a semi-conscious Hardy to their hotel room alone, despite difficulty and exhaustion.
Acknowledges he really did need help but none was forthcoming from the bell boys.
Communicates clearly and honestly about Hardy's condition to Lucille.
Attempts to manage Hardy’s condition without immediate professional medical help.
Feels and expresses apology and regret at not being able to do more or get Hardy to hospital sooner.
Looks miserably at his stricken friend, walks away in a daze with worries on his shoulders, sits dumbstruck unable to act decisively.
Shows concern for Babe Hardy's health and does not consider replacing him despite strong bookings and pressure.
Appears nervous and hesitant when approaching Hardy's hotel room, indicating uncertainty and lack of confidence.
Brings boiled eggs as a thoughtful gift, shares them with Hardy despite his own envy, tries to comfort Hardy about the row with Lucille and about the movie situation.
Offers Hardy to rest and resume when he's better, shows concern for his health.
Feels distress and tries to deny the impact of Hardy's retirement but ultimately supports him.
Initially lies about not working on new scenes, then admits it with a smile and shares an idea, showing playful sincerity.
Denies working on new material when directly asked, initially avoids the question.
Eventually admits to thinking of a new romantic scene and shares creative ideas despite difficult circumstances.
Thinks of a creative, humorous way to handle Hardy's crying by moving a pot plant to catch tears, showing quick thinking and imagination.
Quickly responds to Hardy's needs by handing water, providing blankets, and physically comforting him.
Considers continuing the show with a new partner despite uncertainty, warmly welcomes Nobby Cook, and maintains professionalism.
Hesitates to commit to replacing Hardy immediately, showing some indecision.
Suggests a sensible plan for the run through by going out first and then restarting from the top.
Returns the thumbs up to Cook, trying to reassure him, showing emotional intelligence and supportive skill.
Appears uncomfortable and uncertain listening to Cook practicing lines, reminiscent of Hardy’s past unease.
Pauses, deep in thought before responding to outside threat
Positions himself behind Hardy and taps him on the shoulder as a warning before Hardy gets hurt.
Starts to laugh after Hardy is struck on the head and hurt.
Retaliates by punching Hardy, leading to a shoving match and Hardy falling into the river.
Looks at Hardy blankly after the incident, spreading hands with a guilty, almost childlike expression.
Looks at his own reflection, tired and tearful, showing self-awareness and emotional depth.
Returns a nervous smile to COOK trying out Hardy-style moustache, reassures him with 'That's fine. That's fine.'
Makes a cursory check of his heels and cuffs, trying to convince himself he’s fine before going on stage.
Ida gently takes his cigarette and Scotch away to stop him drinking alone, and he quietly accepts it without resistance.
Reflects to Ida that when watching their movies, no one else knows them and they have only each other.
Sits alone, drinking Scotch and smoking after cancellation of performance, showing withdrawal.
Checks the audience size through a crack in the curtain to mentally prepare before going on stage.
Attempts to self-reassure by checking his costume details (heels and cuffs) despite feeling nervous.
Shows visible anxiety and nervousness before performing.
Does not effectively manage or overcome anxiety before a performance, leading to visible troubled behavior.
Relies on mutual support with Ollie as something stable and secure, indicating emotional intelligence and understanding of their partnership.
Drinking alcohol and smoking alone after a cancelled performance, possibly indicating difficulty coping with professional setbacks.
Says 'I love him Ida,' shows concern about upsetting Babe by cancelling tour, apologizes gently to Ida.
Prepares to leave quietly, respects Ida's instructions about money, shows a somber, thoughtful demeanor.
Tells Ida to deceive Babe about canceling the tour to avoid upsetting him.
Sits gloomily concentrating on the door, appearing resigned but prepared to leave.
Understands without words the gravity of the situation between him and Hardy, shares a meaningful look indicating mutual respect and trust.
Understands unspoken communication from Hardy and responds appropriately, showing perceptiveness and responsiveness.
Brings Hardy below deck after persuasion, showing a sense of responsibility and care.
Gives Hardy back the beret he threw during an argument, admits to lying about the movie, expresses feelings of guilt and concern for Hardy's health.
Carefully puts on gloves finger by finger, showing attention to detail.
Lies about the movie situation, delaying the truth.
Admits to feeling terrible about lying and the situation.
Offers Hardy some food despite knowing he doesn't like it.
Shows concern for Hardy backstage, noticing his exhaustion and suggesting they skip the song for his sake.
Comes up with a creative comedy idea (knocking down a bees' nest onto his own head).
Smiles and waits patiently for his cue.
Makes a humorous but incorrect statement about geography, then realizes his error.
Whispers the correction to Hardy after realizing the mistake.
Matches Hardy’s dance steps perfectly, showing skill and attentiveness.
Refuses to perform without Hardy and chooses to retire.
Continues writing comedy material diligently after retirement.

Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy.Action: Smile and wave back politely to scene hands who imitate their hairstyles and ties.
Laurel screws face into the start of a cry to amuse the scene hands, causing them to laugh.
Pick up their hats but do not put them on before leaving dressing room, then engage politely and humorously with scene hands while walking through studio.
Nod to each other and prepare for a take confidently, showing readiness.
Stan reminds Hardy of their choreographed moves before the take; Hardy confirms understanding.
They begin performing an apparently impromptu dance routine in time with the music, showing timing and coordination.
Laurel tactfully offers to speak to the producer to solve a scheduling conflict.
Engage politely and diplomatically with promoter Delfont to address concerns about tour scheduling and their work commitments.
Appear to rely on Delfont's assurances without visibly pressing for firm solutions.
Left alone on the pavement with their luggage after the taxi driver leaves without assistance, showing a moment of abandonment and possible lack of control over the environment.
Engage in playful sword fight with shoehorn and curtain, imitate each other kneeling on shoes, laugh together until hysterical.
Get stuck kneeling on their shoes and cannot get up again, indicating a lack of foresight or practical competence in that moment.
Politely doff their berets to a woman pushing a pram and later to an elderly couple, showing respect and friendliness.
Perform song and dance together in good spirits for audience, despite disappointing attendance.
Perform together harmoniously, singing and engaging in a playful bowing routine despite physical strain.
Sit silently drinking and smoking after a poorly attended show, failing to show frustration or blame.
Agree to actively publicize their show with personal appearances and extra work for very little or no money.
Help each other (Stan helps Hardy off the train), wave to fans together, perform their humorous bowing routine, sharing laughs.
Playfully wind out tickets from ticket machines and create lighthearted moments that cause laughs among onlookers.
Neither expresses doubt or hesitation about upcoming performances and shows positive forward thinking regarding their careers.
Share excitement together watching London skyline, shaking hands delightedly.
Rehearse lines together and discuss the progress of the movie project thoughtfully.
Seem momentarily distracted by excitement about arriving in London, a non-action/omission reflecting momentary break from focus.
Agree to keep personal appearances private to avoid worrying others.
Quickly dispose of cigarettes and cooperate to perform their public routine politely when photographers arrive.
Have not arrived yet to the after-show party, causing some concern and prompting others to seek them out.
Acknowledge applause embarrassedly and exchange private supportive nods.
Acknowledge applause with embarrassed nods and offer a little bit of business despite the situation, showing professionalism and teamwork.
Discuss practical matters about their work (speaking to Delfont) while showing emotional vulnerability, but do not seem to take immediate steps to resolve issues.
Playfully hiding together behind curtain to avoid guards, enduring threat with humor
React openly with tears and amazement to the crowd’s warm and loving reception
Perform a dance routine together despite physical problems and age, maintaining grace and elegance.

Hal Roach.Action: Storms off angrily and threatens legal action, disrupting the set.

Harry Langdon.Action: Puts hand lightly on Hardy's shoulder in a friendly gesture.

Roach.Action: Tries to enthusiastically promote new partnership implying replacement of Stan with Harry Langdon.

Lucille.Action: Sits next to Hardy and reassures him she values him beyond gifts, showing caring and supportive behavior.
Decides against biting back after Ida’s comment, showing social tact.
Loudly criticizes the situation and the capacity of the project at hand in front of others.
Rolls eyes at Ida’s confusion, showing intolerance.
Upset but not angry about Hardy's situation, indicating tolerance and understanding.

Ida and Laurel.Action: Try to look innocent and offended when nagged about drinking and smoking; playful and tolerant interaction.

Ida.Action: Snatches the Scotch from Stan and drinks it herself to prevent him drinking.
Expresses concern 'I don’t want to lose you Stanley' and gives him a kiss.
Bluntly refers to the 'elephant in the room' causing horrified silence.
Dismisses Lucille’s job as 'script lady' while claiming her own hard work, coming across as dismissive.
